description: From the Middle English sophie, from the Latin sophia, from the Ancient Greek σοφῐ́ᾱ (sophíā, “high knowledge”: “learning”, “wisdom”); compare Sophia.

examples: It had ben) beter to haue kepte the same sophieWhiche þat youre maysteris lerned you first in scole!

entries.meaning: Alternative letter-case form of Sophy (“archaic form of Safawi”).

description: A back-formation from sophies, originally plurale tantum, but later attested in singular use (see the 1678 quotation), itself an irregular Anglicisation of the Latin sophī, whence the English sophi; compare sophy.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A wise man; a sage or wite.
examples: Yet notwithstanding some men in sundrie nations have mounted above the common rate, and indevored to cherish and advaunce the said Insights, and drawen some small sparkes of truth and wisedome out of them, as out of some little fire raked up under a great heape of ashes; the which they have afterward taught unto others, and for so doing have bene called Sophies and Philosophers, that is to say, Wise men and lovers of wisedome.

description: An irregular Anglicisation of sophi; compare sophy ³.

examples: Hange thy selfe Drusus, hast nor arms nor brain?Some Sophy say, The Gods sell all for paine.

description: From the common termination of the class of words denoted (e.g., philosophy, theosophy, etc.); compare the earlier ology and ism, and the later logy and osophy.

entries.meaning: Any one of the various fields of study whose names end in -sophy.
